WallDescription: The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. Detached houses built between 1900 and the mid-1960s were predominantly constructed with monolithic masonry walls, most commonly solid brickwork. This construction method reflects the strong brick-building tradition in the Netherlands. External walls typically ranged from 20 to 35 cm in thickness and provided structural stability but limited thermal performance by modern standards. During the 1960s, many of these houses underwent renovations due to emerging energy regulations. Heating systems were often upgraded, and in some cases internal insulation was added. Occasionally, a second external wall layer was constructed to improve insulation and renew the façade. However, many of these buildings are protected under heritage legislation, which has preserved the original solid brick masonry and limited alterations to the exterior
ArchetypeDescription: Detached houses built up to and including 1964 represent 418,000 homes, representing 5.6% of the Dutch housing stock. Approximately 88% of these are owned by the resident, and approximately 12% are rented. Homes in this category often have 4 to 6 rooms spread over 2 to 4 floors. These homes often have a wooden ground floor. Original Energy Level: In the period up to and including 1964, no energy efficiency requirements were imposed on homes. Therefore, homes were not insulated. Cavity walls were not used until around 1930. Houses built before 1960 often had steel and softwood frames with single glazing. Many homes were equipped with local gas heaters, electric boilers, and natural ventilation during that period. Central heating was used on a limited scale. Current energy level: A large proportion of these homes have been retrofitted with insulation over the years. Almost all homes now have central heating with individual heat generation. The HR107 boiler is the most common (95%). A relatively small number of homes have a different generator (HR100 1%, electric heat pump 2%). For hot water, a gas-fired combination boiler is by far the most commonly used (94%), with some electric boilers (2%) and heat pumps (2%). Retrofitted insulation focuses on installing double glazing (49% of the glass surface) and HR++ glass (29%). 13% of the glass surface in these homes is still single-glazed. Retrofitted insulation of the solid sections is lacking. 58% of the solid facade sections are insulated, 47% of the floor area, 70% of the pitched roof, and 57% of the flat roof. The majority of homes have natural ventilation (90%). The remaining units have mechanical ventilation. Some of the homes are fitted with airtight seals.

WallDescription: The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. In the post-war period, construction techniques shifted toward cavity wall systems. During this era, external walls typically consisted of an inner load-bearing layer made of lightweight concrete or lightweight brick, an uninsulated cavity of approximately 8 cm, and an outer façade layer of about 5 cm thick brickwork. The outer layer was often made of brick, sand-lime brick, or lightweight brick, with occasional use of wooden panels. This construction period followed the Model Bouwverordening (MBV) 1965, which standardized building practices but still placed limited emphasis on thermal insulation.
ArchetypeDescription: Detached houses built between 1965 and 1974 represent 128,500, representing 1.7% of the Dutch housing stock. Homes from this period are all owned by the resident. The homes in this category often have 4 to 6 rooms, spread over 2 to 4 floors. These houses are often traditionally built with load-bearing walls of sand-lime brick and concrete floors. Original Energy Level: Since 1965, requirements have been imposed on the energy quality of homes. However, by current new construction standards, these homes were not very well insulated. Natural ventilation was used to ventilate these homes. Central heating has been increasingly used in this type of home over the years. Current energy level: Some of these homes have been energy-efficiently upgraded over the years. All homes from this period have central heating with individual heat generation. The HR107 boiler is the most common (89%). A smaller proportion of homes have a CR boiler (6%) or an electric heat pump (3%). In addition to gas-fired combination boilers (85%), electric boilers (4%), various types of kitchen heaters or water heaters (9% in total), and heat pumps (2%) are also used for hot water production. Regarding retrofitting, the focus is on installing double glazing (58% of the glass surface) and HR++ glass (24%). Retrofitting of solid sections lags behind slightly. 73% of the solid facade sections are insulated, 35% of the floor area, 76% of the pitched roof, and 57% of the flat roof. The majority of homes have natural ventilation (84%). The remaining portion has mechanical extraction (14%) or balanced ventilation (3%). Some of the homes are equipped with airtight sealing.

WallDescription: The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. From the mid-1970s onward, energy efficiency became a more prominent concern. Cavity walls and multilayer wall systems remained the dominant construction method, but insulation was increasingly added within the cavity. Inner walls were typically constructed from precast concrete or brick masonry, while the outer façade remained a thin brick layer of approximately 5 cm. The cavity was usually filled with EPS (expanded polystyrene) or glass wool insulation, commonly between 5 and 8 cm thick. Façade materials included sand-lime brick, lightweight brick, and occasionally wooden cladding.
ArchetypeDescription: Detached houses built between 1975 and 1991 represent 201,000 homes, representing 2.7% of the Dutch housing stock. The majority, 95%, are owned by the residents, and approximately 5% are rented. Homes in this category often have 4 to 7 rooms spread over 2 to 4 floors. More than half of the homes have three floors. These homes are often traditionally built, but the diversity of these homes is increasing. Original energy level: The energy quality requirements for new-build homes were increased in 1975 (Rc 1.3 m²K/W for roof and solid facade), in 1979 (double glazing in living areas), in 1983 (Rc 1.3 m²K/W ground floor), and in 1988 (Rc 2.0 m²K/W for roof and solid facade). Houses from the first part of this period, in particular, were not very well insulated by current new-build standards. The homes were primarily naturally ventilated. Central heating has become increasingly common over the years. Current energy level: All homes have central heating with individual heat generation. The high-efficiency boiler is the most common (HR107 86% and HR100 6%). A small percentage of homes are heated locally with electricity (3%) or have a heat pump (2%). In addition to combination boilers (91%), electric boilers (4%) and gas water heaters (5%) are also used for hot water production. Double glazing is prevalent (66% of the glass surface). Some of the glass surface of these homes has been upgraded to HR++ glass (20% of the glass surface). Single glazing is still present to a limited extent (4%). Detached homes built after this period no longer have single glazing. All solid facades are insulated, although the insulation level is generally not very high. A large portion of the floors (80%) and roofs (89% sloped, 55% flat) are insulated. Most of the homes have natural ventilation (78%). The remainder have mechanical ventilation (21%). The homes are equipped with airtight seals.

The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. This period followed the introduction of the Bouwbesluit 1992, which significantly raised insulation requirements for walls and other building elements. Detached houses were mainly constructed using multilayer or cavity wall systems with improved thermal performance.
Typical wall assemblies consisted of a thicker load-bearing inner brick layer (approximately 15–22 cm), followed by an insulation layer of 5–8 cm made of EPS or glass wool. The exterior façade layer could be composed of brick, sand-lime brick, brick panels, or wooden cladding. Overall wall thickness and thermal resistance increased compared to earlier periods.
ArchetypeDescription: Detached houses built between 1992 and 2005 represent 196,000 homes, representing approximately 2.6% of the Dutch housing stock. Homes from this period are all owned by the resident. Homes in this category often have 4 to 7 rooms, spread over 2 to 4 floors. The period 1992 to 2005 was characterized by the rise of timber-frame construction and catalog construction for detached houses. However, most were built traditionally with load-bearing walls of sand-lime brick and concrete floors. Original energy level: Houses from this period are well insulated. In 1992, insulation requirements were raised, requiring double glazing and insulation of the facade, floor, and roof (Rc 2.5 m²K/W). High-efficiency boilers were widely used for heating homes. Mechanical ventilation with an extractor fan also gained attention. Current energy level: All homes have central heating with individual heat generation. The high-efficiency boiler is the most common (HR107 89%, HR100 6%, and HR104 2%). In addition to combination boilers (94%), electric boilers (3%) and gas water heaters (2%) are used very rarely for hot water production. Heat pumps account for 1%. None of the detached homes in this period still have single glazing. The glazing is divided between double glazing (39% of the glass surface), high-efficiency glass (16%), high-efficiency glass (10%), and high-efficiency glass (34%). All solid facades, floors, and roofs are insulated, with the insulation level meeting at least the requirements of the construction period (Rc 2.5 m²K/W). The majority of homes are equipped with mechanical ventilation (65%) or natural ventilation (24%). Balanced ventilation is becoming increasingly popular (11%). All homes are equipped with airtight seals.

WallDescription: The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. Construction practices during this period largely continued the trends established between 1992 and 2005, in line with later revisions of the Bouwbesluit (notably the 2012 revision). Wall systems remained primarily cavity or multilayer constructions, with similar material compositions but improved detailing, airtightness, and thermal performance.
ArchetypeDescription: Detached houses built between 2006 and 2014 represent 66,000 homes, representing approximately 0.9% of the Dutch housing stock. Homes from this period are all owned by the resident. Homes in this category often have 4 to 7 rooms, spread over 2 to 4 floors. Detached houses from 2006 to 2014 were also mostly built traditionally (load-bearing walls with sand-lime brick and concrete floors) and, on a modest scale, using timber framing. Original energy level: The houses from this period are well insulated. Between 2006 and 2014, the EPC requirement was tightened from 1.0 to 0.6. This means that houses in this period the insulation needs to be improved during this period. High-efficiency boilers were widely used for heating homes. Balanced ventilation was also a priority. Current energy level: All homes have central heating with individual heat generation (97%), and a small proportion rely on third-party heat supply (3%). The HR107 boiler is the most common (89%). Some homes have a heat pump (8%) or are connected to district heating (third-party heat supply 3%) for both space heating and hot water. Almost all homes have HR++ glass (94%). All solid facades, floors, and roofs are insulated, with the insulation level meeting at least the requirements from the construction period (Rc 2.5 m²K/W). The majority of homes are equipped with balanced ventilation (51%) or mechanical ventilation (45%). Natural ventilation is only present in 2% of homes. All homes are fitted with airtight sealing.

WallDescription: The wall construction of detached houses in the Netherlands has evolved significantly throughout the 20th and early 21st century, mainly driven by changes in construction technology, material availability, and increasingly strict energy regulations. In this most recent period, wall construction types did not change fundamentally. Detached houses continued to use cavity wall or multilayer systems. The main differences lie in the use of higher-performance insulation materials and better thermal conductivity values, driven by stricter energy efficiency standards and sustainability goals. Improved construction quality, reduced thermal bridging, and increased attention to airtightness characterise this era.
ArchetypeDescription: The detached houses built between 2015 and 2018 represent 31,000 homes, approximately 0.4% of the Dutch housing stock. Homes from this period are all owned by the resident. The homes in this category often have 4 to 7 rooms spread over 2 to 5 floors. Over 46% of the homes have three floors, and 31% have five floors. The quality and luxury of the homes increased significantly during this period. Heating costs for these homes are low. In addition, the homes are built with low-maintenance building materials. The architecture and construction methods vary widely, from 1930s styles (brick and overhanging pitched roofs) to ultra-modern (extensive glass, metal, and flat roofs). Original energy level As of April 1, 2012, the Building Decree increased the minimum Rc value (thermal resistance) of floors, facades, and roofs of new buildings from 2.5 to 3.5 m2.K/W. Subsequently, on March 1, 2013, the maximum U-value of windows was tightened from 2.2 to 1.65 W/m2.K. As of January 1, 2015, the minimum Rc value was further tightened to 3.5 for floors, 4.5 for facades and 6.0 for roofs. This means that homes built between 2015 and 2018 have seen a significant increase in insulation levels. Solar panels are also sometimes installed during construction. With the introduction of Nearly Energy Neutral Buildings (BENG), it is mandatory to equip new homes with a sustainable energy generation system. Natural gas-free construction became the norm on July 1, 2018. Current energy level: The vast majority of homes have central heating with individual heat generation (89%) and increasingly, third-party heat supply (11%). The HR107 boiler is still common (36%), but an electric heat pump is increasingly being chosen (53%). A small percentage of homes are connected to district heating (third-party heat supply 11%). The same distribution is used for hot water production. Almost all homes have HR++ glazing (89%). We are also seeing an increasing use of triple glazing (11%). All solid facade sections are insulated, with an insulation level that at least meets current requirements. The majority of homes are equipped with mechanical ventilation (85%). Balanced ventilation is also used (4%), or mechanical ventilation with heat recovery and CO2 control (11%). Natural ventilation is no longer used. All homes are equipped with airtight seals.

WallDescription: The wall construction of semi-detached houses in the Netherlands closely follows the same technological and regulatory developments as detached houses. Differences are mainly found in structural layouts and shared party walls, rather than in external wall construction. Over time, changes in materials, prefabrication methods, and energy regulations strongly influenced wall design. 1900–1964: Solid masonry and early post-war systems. Semi-detached houses built before and shortly after the Second World War were predominantly constructed using solid masonry walls and cavity wall systems, typically in brick. This reflects traditional Dutch construction practices, with external walls usually ranging between 20 and 30 cm in thickness. Thermal insulation was generally absent. In the immediate post-war years, increasing housing demand led to the introduction of more industrialized construction methods. Precast concrete elements, steel frame constructions, and standardized building components were increasingly used, particularly in larger housing developments. External walls often consisted of structural concrete or masonry with brick cladding, but insulation levels remained low or nonexistent.
ArchetypeDescription: Semi-detached houses built up to and including 1964 represent approximately 4.4% of the Dutch housing stock, comprising 330,000 homes. Of these, 80% are owned by the resident, and 20% are rented. The homes in this category often have 4 to 5 rooms spread over 2 to 4 floors. Half of the homes have two floors. These homes often have high-ceilinged rooms on the ground floor and a wooden ground floor. These wooden ground floors were common in this type of home until the late 1970s. Original Energy Level: Until 1965, no energy efficiency requirements were imposed on homes. Therefore, the homes were not insulated. Cavity walls were not used until around 1930. Homes built before 1960 often had steel window frames and softwood window frames with single glazing. Many homes at that time were equipped with local gas heaters, electric boilers, and natural ventilation. Central heating was used on a limited scale. Current energy level: Some of these homes have been energy-efficiently upgraded over the years. All homes now have central heating with individual heat generation. The HR107 boiler is the most common (88%). A small percentage of homes have a VR boiler (3%) or a local gas or oil heater (4%). In addition to combination boilers (93%), gas bath or kitchen water heaters (5%) and occasionally heat pumps (1%) are also used for hot water production. Post-insulation focuses on installing double glazing (52% of the glass surface) and HR++ glass (25%). A substantial portion of single glazing remains (15%). Post-insulation of the sealed sections lags behind. Of the solid facade sections, 49% are insulated, of the floor area 40%, of the pitched roof 68%, and of the flat roof 59%. Most of the homes have natural ventilation (89%). The remainder primarily have mechanical ventilation (9%). Some of the homes are equipped with airtight sealing.

ArchetypeDescription:
The remaining apartment buildings built between 1992 and 2005 represent 128,000 units, representing approximately 1.7% of the Dutch housing stock. Nearly half of these homes are rented (48%). The remaining half are owner-occupied (52%). Homes in this category often have three rooms. These single-story homes are part of a multi-story building. They are accessible via a central hall or corridor. A characteristic of this construction period is that few apartments were built traditionally. Prefabricated construction was the most common construction method. Original energy level: The homes from this period were well insulated. In 1992, insulation requirements were raised, making double glazing and insulation of the facade, floor, and roof (Rc 2.5 m²K/W) commonplace. The homes were often equipped with (individual) central heating with a VR boiler and mechanical ventilation. Current energy level: All homes have central heating. Individual heating is the most common (88%), along with heat supplied by third parties (11%) and, to a very limited extent, collective heating (1%). For individual heating, the HR107 combination boiler is most common (86%), and a small proportion of homes have a VR boiler (2%). Hot water is primarily heated by individual combination boilers (88%) and, to a very limited extent, by kitchen water heaters (1%).
All homes were fitted with double glazing (44% of the glass surface) or HR++ glass (43%) upon completion. Single glazing is still used to a very limited extent (1%). The remaining glass surface is HR (6%) or HR+ (6%). All solid facades, floors, and roofs are insulated, with the insulation level meeting at least the requirements from the construction period (Rc 2.5 m²K/W). Most homes are equipped with mechanical ventilation (88%). In addition, balanced ventilation is becoming increasingly popular (11%), and limited mechanical ventilation with heat recovery and control is used (1%). Fully natural ventilation is no longer used. All homes are equipped with airtight seals.

WallDescription: The wall construction of apartment buildings in the Netherlands has historically differed from that of single-family housing due to scale, structural demands, and the need for rapid housing production. Especially after the Second World War, apartment construction became strongly associated with industrialized, prefabricated concrete systems. Over time, energy regulations gradually improved thermal performance, but changes occurred more slowly than in detached and semi-detached housing. 2006–2014: Higher insulation requirements (Bouwbesluit 2012 revised). During this period, apartment construction continued to rely on concrete-based structural systems, in line with revised energy performance requirements under the Bouwbesluit 2012. External walls typically consisted of 15–25 cm thick load-bearing concrete elements combined with increased insulation thickness and improved thermal detailing. While construction typologies remained similar to those of the previous period, insulation values and airtightness were further improved.
ArchetypeDescription:
The remaining apartment buildings built between 2006 and 2014 represent 109,500 units, representing approximately 1.5% of the Dutch housing stock. More than half of the units are rented (71%), while the remaining 29% are owner-occupied.
The units in this category often have three rooms. The single-story units are part of a multi-story building. They are accessible via a central hall or corridor. A characteristic of this construction period is that few apartment buildings were built traditionally. Cast-in and prefabricated concrete construction was the most common construction method. Original energy level: The homes from this period were well insulated. Between 2006 and 2014, the EPC requirement was tightened from 1.0 to 0.6. As a result, homes from this period were even better insulated. High-efficiency boilers were widely used for heating the homes. Balanced ventilation was also emphasized. Current energy level: All homes have central heating. Individual heating is the most common (45%), followed by collective heating (32%) and heat supplied by third parties (23%). For individual heating, the HR107 combination boiler is the most common (42%). A small proportion of homes have a heat pump (3%). The same distribution applies to hot water heating using individual combination boilers (42%), heat pumps (3%), or collective heating systems (32%), and heat supplied by third parties (23%). All homes were fitted with high-efficiency glass (19% of the glass surface) or HR++ glass (75%) upon completion. Single glazing (2%) and double glazing (2%) are still used to a very limited extent. All solid facade sections are insulated, with an insulation level that at least meets current requirements (Rc 2.5 m²K/W). More than two-thirds of homes are equipped with mechanical ventilation (71%). The remaining homes are equipped with balanced ventilation (29%). All homes are fitted with airtight sealing.

WallDescription: The wall construction of apartment buildings in the Netherlands has historically differed from that of single-family housing due to scale, structural demands, and the need for rapid housing production. Especially after the Second World War, apartment construction became strongly associated with industrialized, prefabricated concrete systems. Over time, energy regulations gradually improved thermal performance, but changes occurred more slowly than in detached and semi-detached housing. 2015–2018: Optimized concrete wall systems. Apartment buildings constructed between 2015 and 2018 show no fundamental change in wall construction type compared to the preceding period. Concrete remains the dominant load-bearing material, with wall thicknesses generally between 15 and 25 cm. However, insulation performance improved further through the use of higher-quality materials and better integration of insulation layers. These buildings typically exhibit medium to good thermal performance, reflecting stricter energy efficiency standards and improved construction practices.
ArchetypeDescription:
The remaining apartment buildings built between 2015 and 2018 represent approximately 0.3% of the Dutch housing stock, totaling 18,500. Most of these properties are rented (72%), with the remaining 28% being owner-occupied.
These properties often have three rooms. Single-story apartments are part of a multi-story building. They are accessible via a central hall or corridor. A characteristic of this construction period is that few apartments were built traditionally. Cast-in and prefabricated concrete construction was the most common construction method. Original energy level: As of April 1, 2012, the Building Decree increased the minimum Rc value (thermal resistance) of floors, facades, and roofs of new buildings from 2.5 to 3.5 m².K/W. Subsequently, on March 1, 2013, the maximum U-value of windows was tightened from 2.2 to 1.65 W/m².K. As of January 1, 2015, the minimum Rc value was further tightened to 3.5 for floors, 4.5 for facades, and 6.0 for roofs. This means that homes built between 2015 and 2018 will see a significant increase in insulation level. Solar panels are also sometimes installed during construction. With the introduction of BENG (Netherlands Energy Efficiency Directive), it is mandatory to equip new homes with a sustainable energy generation system. As of July 1, 2018, natural gas-free construction is the standard. Current energy level: All homes have central heating. Collective heating is the most common (62%), followed by individual heating (38%). For individual heating, only the HR107 combination boiler is used (38%). Domestic hot water is also heated exclusively by these HR107 combination boilers (38%). Almost all homes were fitted with HR++ glass upon completion (96% of the glass surface). HR glass was used to a very limited extent (3%). Single and double glazing are no longer present.
All solid facades, floors, and roofs are insulated, with the insulation level meeting at least the requirements from the construction period. Almost all homes are equipped with mechanical ventilation (63%) or mechanical ventilation with heat recovery and CO2 control (36%). Balanced ventilation is also used to a limited extent (1%). All homes are fitted with airtight seals.
